title: 115_s354
content: The Act is known as the "Reforming American Immigration for Strong Employment Act" or the "RAISE Act". It eliminates the Diversity Visa Program. Section 203 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended by removing subsection (c). Additionally, technical and conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Act. In section 203 of the Immigration and Nationality Act, subsections (d), (e), (f), (g), and (h) are redesignated as subsections (c), (d), (e), (f), and (g) respectively. Subsection (c) is amended to refer to subsection (a) or (b) instead of (a), (b), or (c). Additionally, paragraph (2) is struck from subsection (d) and paragraph (3) is redesignated. In section 203 of the Immigration and Nationality Act, subsections (d), (e), (f), (g), and (h) are redesignated as subsections (c), (d), (e), (f), and (g) respectively. Subsection (c) is amended to refer to subsection (a) or (b) instead of (a), (b), or (c). Additionally, paragraph (3) is redesignated in subsection (d). In section 204, amendments are made by striking certain subparagraphs and subsection references and inserting new ones. Amendments are made in various sections by striking references to "section 203(d)" and replacing them with "section 203(c)". Additionally, the immigrant investor pilot program is amended by removing reference to "section 203(e)". The amendment replaces references to "section 203(e)" with "section 203(d)" in the Immigration Act. The effective date for these changes is the first day of the fiscal year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 3 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to limit the annual admission of refugees to 50,000. The President must report the number of aliens granted asylum each year. "Attorney General" is replaced with "Secretary of Homeland Security." SEC. 4 focuses on family-sponsored immigration priorities. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to redefine immediate relatives as only children and spouses of US citizens. The worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrants is set at 88,000 minus a calculated number for each fiscal year. The worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrants is set at 88,000 minus a calculated number for each fiscal year, based on the number of aliens paroled into the US under specific conditions. Section 203(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include spouses and minor children of permanent resident aliens as qualified immigrants. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the definition of a V nonimmigrant in the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change the numerical limitation for family-sponsored immigrants, with 75 percent of visa numbers issued without per country limitation. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allocate 25 percent of visa numbers under section 203(a) to countries subject to subsection (e) if their visa issuance is below the subsection (e) ceiling, defined as 77 percent of the maximum number of visas. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allocate 25 percent of visa numbers under section 203(a) to countries subject to subsection (e) if their visa issuance is below the subsection (e) ceiling, defined as 77 percent of the maximum number of visas. Amendments include striking certain subparagraphs and redesignating paragraphs. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allocate visa numbers under section 203(a) to countries subject to subsection (e) if their visa issuance is below the subsection (e) ceiling. Amendments include striking certain subparagraphs and redesignating paragraphs for determining immigrant status. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allocate visa numbers under section 203(a) to countries subject to subsection (e) if their visa issuance is below the subsection (e) ceiling. Amendments include striking certain subparagraphs and redesignating paragraphs for determining immigrant status. In subsection (f)(1), changes are made by striking certain terms and inserting new language regarding individuals younger than 21 years of age for petition adjudication and admission as immediate relatives or family-sponsored immigrants. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to reallocate visa numbers under section 203(a) to countries under subsection (e) if their visa issuance is below the subsection (e) ceiling. Amendments involve striking specific terms and redesignating paragraphs for determining immigrant status, including waivers of inadmissibility and employment of nonimmigrants. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to create a nonimmigrant classification for alien parents of adult United States citizens by reallocating visa numbers under section 203(a) and redesignating paragraphs for determining immigrant status. Amendments involve striking specific terms and inserting new language in various subparagraphs. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to create a nonimmigrant classification for alien parents of adult United States citizens. The amendment includes conditions on admission, such as a five-year initial period of authorized admission that can be extended if the US citizen child is still residing in the country. Nonimmigrants in this category are not allowed to work in the US or receive any public benefits. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to create a nonimmigrant classification for alien parents of adult United States citizens. Nonimmigrants in this category are not eligible for any public benefits and must have health insurance arranged by their US citizen child. The amendments take effect at the beginning of the fiscal year. The amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act create a nonimmigrant classification for alien parents of adult US citizens, effective at the start of the fiscal year. Any petitions seeking classification of an alien under a family-sponsored immigrant category that was eliminated by the amendments will be considered invalid if filed after the introduction of the Act.
